last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>619784296
>What the fuck was Microsoft thinking
They thought the price per transistor wasn't going down anymore, so die shrinks wouldn't lead to price savings in the future. Because of that, a slim model midway through the gen was no longer possible, and neither would be the price savings for Microsoft or their customers that come along with it that drive sales. Instead, they decided to launch with a "slim" version of their console, but with a gutted GPU to make up for the price difference to hit that magical $299 price point they thought they needed.

The problem with all of this was because they're now splitting their parts into 2 completely different SKUs, they don't get the massive price reductions that come with volume they otherwise would. Also, they went with a huge die size on their Series X which was very expensive, and even the cut down Series S die is also so expensive for them that they're losing $200 a unit. Series X is losing about $100 a unit still. In contrast, Sony got their disc model to break even point over a year ago, and with their 6nm die shrink they can now produce twice as many PS5 chips per wafer than Microsoft can produce Series X chips per wafer, effectively fixing their supply problem.
Nobody wanted the S so it never even got scalped, and Microsoft has had to do numerous promotions to even sell the things. We've routinely seen it hit $249, $249 bundled with an extra controller, $259 bundled with the new CoD, $219 on Woot, and even $199 on Instagram.
